title: Instruments
text:
The pipe organ has a vast history extending to ancient Alexandria, but the instrument began to more closely resemble what we see today during the Middle Ages in Europe, where it became a staple of Roman Catholic liturgy. Although instruments across the continent had similar traits and mechanics, by the Baroque era there were sweeping regional differences in construction and especially in tonal design. Even though the centuries of intervening development and global diffusion of technique mean that, for example, French Romantic traits can be observed in instruments from Charlestown to China, one can still identify national schools of organbuilding in modern-day work.
On a more concrete level, each organbuilder and each instrument for the most part are quite unique. The design and execution of a pipe organ (both visual and tonal) has always been a lengthy endeavor highly influenced both by prevailing stylistic ideals and the acoustical parameters of the church or hall for which it is built. Add to this variety the observation that no two stops of the same name on two different instruments ever sound fully alike (for even if they are built identically they are subject to different acoustics), and comparative analysis of pipe organs becomes quite a fascinating subject.
Here the sheer volume of the Internet comes into play.

Stop Name References
If uncertain as to what a stop name means, see this brief table (Wikipedia) or the online Encyclopedia of Organ Stops, which also has some sound clips of registers in isolation (mostly from digital samplesets in turn recorded from actual instruments).

title: Instruments
text:
General Databases
These contain detailed stoplists, photographs, and historical information for many of the world’s pipe organs. Most are limited to a particular country or region. There is a good chance that any large acoustic pipe organ heard in a recording or on YouTube can be found on one of these sites.

Die Orgelseite (Germany/Global)
Although much of the content is behind a paywall, the site provides stoplists and photos for the largest instruments in Germany, the US, and some others. There is also a ranked list of the largest instruments and a list of uncommon features of certain instruments.


pipeorgandatabase.org (USA/North America)
Created by the Organ Historical Society. Contains information on over 70,000 pipe organs in North America, with many excellent photographs.


The National Pipe Organ Register (UK)


Inventory of Organs (France)


The Organs of Paris (Paris, France)
Detailed information on the about 278 pipe organs in Paris, including a historical breakdown of when they were built.

title: Instruments
text:
Builder’s Lists
Most current and some former organbuilders maintain lists of their instruments. A few such are:

Skinner/Aeolian-Skinner (formerly of Methuen and Boston, MA)
Lists of factory specifications; a few photographs. Aeolian-Skinner was the definitive American Classic organbuilder under G. Donald Harrison in the early-to-mid 20th century.


Casavant (Saint-Hyacinthe, Quebec)
One of the oldest and most prolific builders in North America. Site contains photos of over 30 curated instruments with descriptions and stoplists.


C.B. Fisk (Gloucester, MA)
A leading American mechanical-action builder and pioneer of the use of carbon fiber for tracker action. Site has a geographical list of most of their work.

title: Technique
text:
Although organ keyboard technique bears obvious resemblance to that of the piano, the fundamental difference is that a key on one of a pipe organ’s manuals is much more like a switch, and there is no sustain pedal to prolong the note after the key is released.
Therefore, organists must precisely control the timing of the attack and release of the key in order to sculpt articulation and phrasing.
Because the lack of sustain means that a break between notes is more obvious than on the piano, organists make frequent use of pure legato articulation, to such an extent that “always play legato” has sometimes been made an axiom, even with the works of J.S. Bach.
On the opposite extreme, the preoccupation with so-called “historically informed practice” in the mid-to-late 20th century meant that some organists used almost exclusively detached or (semi-)staccato articulation for Baroque composers, again including Bach.
Both of these views are severe generalizations that risk sacrificing the musicality and gravitas of many works, especially those of Bach. The correct answer is probably that articulation should be defined by the requirements of the music at hand, taking into reasonable account both the likely intentions of the composer and the specific needs of a given phrase in a given acoustical environment.
The point of this discursus is that consumption of both the below textbooks and of many Bach organ performances often requires a few grains of salt.

title: Technique
text:
Classic Texts
There is much overlapping information in the following old textbooks, and all three teach the “Bach legato”. I would suggest beginning with Stainer and referencing Dupré, with Barnes as a supplemental resource. Stainer dwells longer on the basics, while Dupré quite quickly dives into complicated finger substitutions, etc. Stainer also contains illustrated descriptions of pipe organ key and stop action.






Note



The usual caveats of musical self-study apply here (the risk of engraining ‘bad’ technique, etc.). Of course, the ideal would be to study with an excellent pedagogue within one’s own church tradition. However, where this is not feasible, I am more inclined than most to encourage going it on one’s own, especially because good piano technique forms a solid and necessary basis for organ playing (with a few modifications, described in the textbooks below), and good piano instruction is easier to find. More generally, good technique follows a few simple principles, including:

Always strive to exert the least effort. The best motion is the simplest, most relaxed, and least irritating (in other words, the “principle of minimal movement” applies). This necessitates a good pianistic foundation of finger strength/independence and natural hand shape at the keyboard.
Be able to play in perfect legato wherever feasible. Of course, one may decide to use a fingering or pedalling which only allows detached articulation if this is consistent with good interpretation, but only if this is easier and less strenuous (according to the first principle above).
Begin practicing at a speed which allows conscious control of every motion. When first starting out, this may mean playing one note every five seconds. That’s fine! Start there and progress as able.




The Organ (1877/1909) by Sir John Stainer (ed. Harker)
Méthode d’orgue (1927) by Marcel Dupré
School of Organ Playing (1921) by E.S. Barnes

title: Repertoire
text:
Although many composers in the broader Western classical canon were also organists and composed for the instrument (J.S. Bach, Mozart, Mendelssohn, Franck, Liszt, Brahms, and Bruckner, to name a few), many central figures in the organ repertoire are relatively unknown to non-organists.

title: A Pipe Organ Compendium
text:
Introduction
The goal of this site is to assist the student of the pipe organ by collecting and contextualizing some of the many freely available Internet resources pertaining to the instrument.
It is not intended as either a complete introduction to the pipe organ or a scholarly review of relevant resources. Rather, it serves to facilitate the rapid discovery and comprehension of some of the many existing resources on a variety of topics that I have found over the years.
Links to the Compendium’s resource pages may be found in the header above.
(To whet your intellectual and musical appetite, enjoy this recording of early 20th-century Canadian-American organ virtuoso Lynwood Farnam’s Toccata by British-Australian organist Simon Nieminski.)
